title: Wildbook takes over Bing’s homepage for a day | College of Engineering | University of Illinois at Chicago
contents: Skip to the content of this page ,  the main menu , the site search form , the site home page .           College of Engineering     Search the site     Toggle Menu      Search                  College of Engineering      College of Engineering   Main Menu    Undergraduate           Admitted Student Information    Admissions    Advising    Career Outcomes    Diversity    Engineering Expo    FAQ    Majors and Minors    Paid Internships    Scholarships    Student Groups    Student Resources    Women in Engineering         Graduate    Departments    Research           Interdisciplinary Research    Labs and Centers         Support UIC           Donate Online    How to Give    Help Students    Empower Faculty    Capital Projects         About           Dean    Faculty    Administration    Staff    Alumni    Advisory Board    Facilities    Summer Camp    News    Contact          Eyebrow menu    Give    Careers    Alumni    UIC menu    UIC.edu    Campus Map       Search                     Wildbook takes over Bing’s homepage for a day    Posted on August 15, 2018         story title      Professor Tanya Berger-Wolf’s Wildbook project was featured on the Bing search engine homepage on August 14th.  The homepage featured the endangered Grevy’s zebra, an animal whose population Wildbook has aimed to help conserve using AI and crowd-sourced photography. Wildbook is a part of Wild Me , an established non-profit that Berger-Wolf oversees with her team of conservation enthusiasts. The group has helped take a more accurate census of thousands of endangered species, including giraffes, elephants, and whale sharks, among others.  In addition to the featured image, Bing hosted a three-question quiz for users to test their zebra knowledge. Wildbook’s collaboration with Bing stems from its relationship with parent company Microsoft.  Microsoft recently announced Wild Me as one of their five featured projects for its AI for Earth initiative, which includes a $50 million commitment toward utilizing AI to help protect the planet and its inhabitants.      story title        Visit Wildbook          Take Quiz          Modified on August 12, 2019
